content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Recursive algorithm, it works.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: there are few gotchas - the input is provided in chunks, but you operate on combined string. If there's a limitation on CG side, then maybe its worth mentioning that you have to combine it or carry over checks between chunks in the description. 
Otherwise its quite fun puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like it. There were several tricky corner cases that caught me out. Every fail was in a test case, not a validator.

Hi there, I enjoyed this problem.  

Quick question: for test 2, why is the pair "ff" replaced with W, as it seems there is only one non-overlapping pair.

My output:
Failure
Found: aeXfffbdXacZd...
Expected: aeXWfbdXacZd

Maybe I am a little confused from the problem statement, but my take is:

From step 1, it says "note: we only count (and replace) non-overlapping repetitions."  Further, "each iteration reduces the length of the string by at least 2" so we should have a minimum of two replacements.  Here, only one "W" is in the output.  "There are now no repeated byte pairs, so the algorithm terminates."
That's a great spot, thank you! The problem description is correct, the test cases and solution are wrong. I've updated both - please let me know if your solution agrees!
Thanks so much for the approval!
Thanks for the feedback! I've added a line at the end of the description to clarify.
Works now, thanks for the quick update!  I would probably put this between easy/medium, but I enjoyed it nonetheless.
